speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: To the people who don't know me, so as both a deployment strategist at COGSAC and as a non-resident fellow at the Atlantic Council, I facilitate interdisciplinary teams producing research on topics like gray zone warfare, education and knowledge management technology, intelligence analysis, and on complexity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And like I said, maybe today I won't talk about complexity specifically, but about some of the practical aspects of working on remote emergent teams, which, Dan, you are familiar with, because you are on many of these teams.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, yeah, I thought this would be the right thing to talk about, especially because the upcoming weekend and for people watching, if you're not attending that weekend, you're going to get a sense of the community.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Maybe it's still useful, but I also strongly recommend you still attend.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I guess the good starting point is that there's some literature and intelligence analysis which suggests something that kind of frustrates me, which is that as the structural complexity of the information environment around you increases past a certain threshold, so like think interconnectedness, confounding variables, blind spots in data, unpredictability in general, there are kind of two natural paths, like water running downhill, that we tend toward.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we either get withdrawal from the environment and effective elimination, which is usually not fast.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We kind of slowly back away.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you want to get a very real sense of this, I feel like talking to people who say like they don't watch the news anymore to kind of get a more visceral explanation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But anyone that's been on a lot of committees or working groups or teams in general knows this super well, even if they don't want to think about it too much, this kind of slow backing away of I'm not sure what's going on.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I'm not sure what it is we're doing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Or we actually get increased confidence, which is the frustrating part for me.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we get faster response times and poor decision making.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this area of research is under the umbrella of cognitive overload.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So there's some interesting studies on that, like on horse betting, analyzing French grammar, of all things, and on decision making under pressure.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So as you know, I like to phrase it this way.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: When the brain can't reduce the complexity of the environment out there, it reduces the complexity of the strategy it uses to make sense of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we start to filter out important information.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We compress on things like narrative identity, which for social scientists listening, it's like concept of homophily, like our tendency to listen to and trust people who think and act like us.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then we could also maintain continuous partial attention, never really integrate things or move toward action.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Or we sort of LARP.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So like live action role play our way through the environment, relying on social scripts.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So these are problems for teams because none of this is good if you want to actually try to move toward productive work.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this is especially a huge set of challenges for teams that are emergent because we can't rely on mutual norms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They're not established yet.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is probably our first time working together.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And we also can't rely on the stick, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Like emergent teams rarely have a parent organization making performance demands with paycheck as leverage.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Complexity weekend is going to kick you out if you fail to produce work.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You usually don't have the grant yet.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You don't have funding yet.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So there's no contractual reliability or relationship within the team.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I don't know if Scott David is watching, but I'm sure he's going to start posting in the live chat if
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: After talking about contractual reliability.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: He's a facilitator, he's great.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then further, it's especially a problem for teams which are interdisciplinary and addressing complexity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Because on one side, you have the complexity of the problem, interconnectedness, confounding variables, and predictability.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But on another, you have the source literature addressing it, which is also coming from a variety of domains.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: just learning curves for application and figuring out goodness of fit.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I find this all the time.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I don't know anything about statistical mechanics, but it's going to be tremendously important in so many different places.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then again, further, you have the structural complexity of the team itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So capabilities, knowledge, interests, boundaries, all this, especially as you increase beyond a dyad to four or more people.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So after spending the last two years or so
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: being continuously involved in one or more emergent teams and seeing them form, norm, perform, and stay together over time, as well as seeing them not norm and perform and seeing many disintegrate, there are blood and bones on the path.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's sort of perilous.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So being on emergent teams though, obviously,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: can be a hugely rewarding experience.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And some of the teams I've been on that formed a Complexity Weekend, one that I was on with you, you know, completely changed my life, career trajectory, given me tons of opportunities because of this interconnectedness between the individuals, the relationships they have with different organizations.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But I think like key piece of advice is do not rely on luck or enthusiasm.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is just saying in the user experience and design communities, like don't rely on creativity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Even a short amount of time, I figured there's a few things we can go through that make sure your team is always on the move toward moving toward producing meaningful work.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So first, and this
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I know you know that I never shut up about is goal setting gets getting super clear about your mission.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What is it your team is actually trying to accomplish?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Mission should be clear and really easy to communicate both within the team and to outsiders.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And it should be measurable or if it's a sort of binary, if you succeeded, there should be no question.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It should be really obvious that the mission was completed.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this is honestly the biggest thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you have a clear mission, you've won half the battle.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So many teams and organizations in general run into this problem of all scales, shifting goalposts, mission creep.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So then second is scoping the work.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So getting super clear about the approach to that mission, who's doing what, what's expected of team members, milestones.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I used to think this was work about work or bureaucratic.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then looking back at the time that I felt that versus the time that I accepted it as something you need to do, the amount of work produced is just incomparable.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's just not work about work.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It is like the work that's necessary for work to continue.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Every high reliability organization in the world does this for a reason.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You know, always scoping the work, always setting out a clear mission.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Then flexibility.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So changing your mission, your approach, like,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: These actually can be good things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I like to think of it this way.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There's a person I spoke to from Department of Defense last week, and they said, be disciplined, not rigid.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I really like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's just a matter of documenting your changes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you're going to change, that's good, but make sure you change it so that you're not only accountable to the new mission and the new approach and work, but also so that you're accountable to the change.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Then facilitation, our meme, get someone to facilitate the team, not manage it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's super important because you're an emergent team.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Nobody's technically in charge.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Nobody's the principal owner of the work, but that doesn't mean it can just be leaderless.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You do need somebody to manage the work in the sense of managing the resources, not managing the people, and facilitating people toward meaningful action.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There are a couple of tools that can be used to do this, one of which we created.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I always highly recommend the Facilitators Catechism.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I can't share the link right now, but if you were to keep listening, if you search Google for Facilitators Catechism Playbook, you'll find our recent short book on using simple to implement project documentation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And there are others, but I think those are important items to keep in mind.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then I guess like a few other things that
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: are more tips and things to keep in mind, not necessarily process that you do, that I felt like would be helpful to note.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So one is that high performance teams have a good ratio between inquiry and advocacy, which is to say that teams which disagree on everything rarely perform, but teams that agree on everything immediately also rarely perform, which I thought was interesting.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The higher the impact of individual inputs on final group decisions,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: the higher the related performance of the team.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I'm not sure, I would love to talk to you about that afterward, like why that is, because there's some reasons that come to mind, but I'm not sure about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But then the higher the degree of, and I thought this was super important, especially for Complexity Weekend, is the higher the degree of input of resources on subject matter from individual knowledge at the start of the project, the higher the quality of group performance later on.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So many people wait to push information from their fields or conflict avoidance.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So it's apparently, and this is from a meta-analysis I can link later, but apparently the earlier the better.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So don't be afraid of throwing too many resources, everybody's not going to read all of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But putting it out there, you don't have low expectations.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Some people will go through and read all the material you put out.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Um, then, uh, and this wouldn't be an RJ talk, unless I talk about either wolves or a Republic of Ragusa.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Uh, so today you get wolves.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Uh, there are a few studies that show that wolves actually out-competed trained domestic dogs on cooperative tasks.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the reason was that domesticated dogs were being too domestic.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They were too conflict avoidant to work out role conflict early into the tasks.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So like sparring isn't fighting is the phrasing you had brought up to me recently.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's like there's an importance in allowing for some conflict and disagreement because escalating a little now can mean no conflict escalation later.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And finally, I think is equal voice doesn't necessarily mean higher performance.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Some people, everybody has different personalities.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if someone hasn't talked in a bit, that's okay.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But this is why you should have a facilitator present in these teams, because they need to be able to recognize that somebody hasn't been in the conversation for a long time.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You know, sometimes people want to gestate and really think about what's being brought in front of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They don't have a comment on everything yet.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So you do need a facilitator.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You do need that awareness to try to bring people back into the conversation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They haven't been involved in a while.
